questions.text: 25 yr old male complaints of a gradually progressing swelling around wrist for 3 months. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Above xray image shows soap bubble appearance which is diagnostic sign for giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma
  • The X ray depicts the diagnostic Soap bubble appearance of a Giant cell tumor which is one of the commonest tumors to be seen in distal end of radius.
  • However, the commonest sites for the GCT per say are: Distal femur Proximal tibia Distal radius.
  • It’s a benign lesion with 3% mets to lung
  • On clinical examination: egg shell cracking

Giant cell tumor/ osteoclastoma:

AGE (YR): 20-40 Slight female predominance

SITE: Distal femur>Proximal tibia>Distal radius

PRESENTATION: Pain, Pathologic fracture (10%-30%), Egg shell cracking sound on tapping the lesion is heard

IMAGING:

  • Eccentrically located in epiphysis
  • Purely radiolucent (no matrix formation) Soap bubble appearance
  • Usually no rim of reactive bone
  • Abuts subchondral bone
  • May exhibit cortical destruction with soft tissue extension
  • Metaphyseal in skeletally immature patients

HISTOLOGY:

  • Multinucleated giant cells in sea of mononuclear cells
  • Nuclei of mononuclear stromal cells identical to nuclei of giant cells- these are the actual tumor cells and not the giant cells. These stromal cells produce RANk ligands which stimulate the osteoclast further causing destruction of the bone

TREATMENT:

  • Extended curettage Resection if residual bone stock inadequate with phenol or liquid nitrogen
  • Denosumab can also be used in GCT’s present in inaccessible areas
  • Consider radiation for spinal/ sacral tumors Resection of pulmonary metastases

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 7th edition page no 232

questions.text: 26yr old male with backache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes presented to the OPD. His X-RAY of the spine is given below. Most likely diagnosis for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Points in favour of ankylosing spondylosis are

  1. Male gender
  2. Age between 15 to 35 years
  3. Back pain for 3 months
  4. Back stiffness due ankylosis of vertebrae.
  5. Reduced chest expansion which occurs due to the ankylosis of the costovertebral junctions.
  6. Red eye which in due to anterior uveitis. Uveitis is the most common extra articular manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis.

X-ray finding in ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS:

  1. Earliest sign - b\l sacroilitis
  2. Bamboo spine
  3. Shiny corner sign
  4. Dagger sign

Bamboo spine.

Romanus sign (shiny corner sign)

Dagger sign spine

Extraskeletal manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis

  • Atlantoaxila subluxation
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Apical lung fibrosis
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • AV conduction block
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Amyloidosis
  • Achilles enthesitis

Option c) Paget's disease- it cannot be the answer as it's presentation is after 50yrs

Reference: Rothman-Simeone spine, Page 637.

questions.text: 5 year old child presented with bilateral genu Varun. X-RAY of the child Is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above given image is of a bow legs (bilateral genital varum)

  • The most common cause of bilateral genital varum in children- RICKETS (vitamin D deficiency)
  • Presentation of rickets:
    1. b\l genu varum (bow legs)
    2. B\l genu Valgum (knock knees)
    3. Windswept deformity

The x ray shows the classical changes of rickets in the distal femur and proximal tibia. These include

  1. Bilateral genu varum
  2. Metaphyseal splaying (widening)
  3. Metaphyseal cupping
  4. Metaphyseal fraying

Option b) SCURVY

X-RAY changes in scurvy:

  • Diaphysis
    • Osteopenia- earliest sign
    • Ground glass appearance
    • Pencil thin cortex
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Metaphysis
    • Frankel’s white line
    • Trummerfeld zone
    • Pelican spur
  • Epiphysis
    • Wimberger sign

Option c) OSTEOMALACIA

X-RAY finding in osteomalacia:

  • Looser zones:
    • Milkman fractures
    • Pseudo fractures
    • Transverse fracture lines perpendicular to long axis of bone
    • Most common site neck of femur
    • Also seen in clavicle, ribs, scapula, pubic ramus

Option d) Osteopetrosis:

X-RAY findings in osteopetrosis:

  • Diffuse sclerosis of bones
  • Lack of cortico-cancellous differentiation
  • Narrow/absent medullary Canal
  • Endobones(‘Os in Os’ appearance)
  • Sandwich vertebrae
  • Erlenmeyer flask appearance

Reference: Tachdjian's Pediatric Orthopaedics, 6th edition, Page no. 1934.

choices.text: Teriperatide should be started before supplementing bisphosphonates
Bisphophonates not given for more than a year
Calcium required is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium

questions.text: An elderly female with history of Colle's fracture is complaining of back ache. Which of the given statement is wrong in relation to treatment of this patient.
questions.solution:
Treatment of osteoporosis

Problems of using bisphophonates:

  • Prolong fracture healing
  • Chronic use causes atypical fractures (subtrochanteric fractures of femur)
  • Prevention: by giving drug holiday (bisphosphiantes stopped after 5yr use and restarted after 2-3yrs bridged with teriperatide in absence of bisphophonates)

Supplements used in osteoporosis:

  • Calcium- 800-1200mg/day
  • Vitamin D- 400-800 IU/day
  • Calcitonin (nasal spray)- 200-400 IU/day (mainly used for pain relief

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 309

questions.text: A patient fell down from bicycle and started having pain around hip. O/E there is shortening of limb and attitude was flexion, adduction, internal rotation of hip. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 130

questions.text: 50 yr old male presented with weakness of grasp. The examiner performed the following test. Which nerve is being tested here?
questions.solution:
The above image shows: pen test which test abductor of thumb which is abductor pollicis brevis – innervated by median nerve

MEDIAN NERVE INJURY AT WRIST :

  • Muscles involved:
  • Abductor pollicis brevis- loss of thumb abduction
  • Flexor pollicis brevis- loss of thumb flexion
  • Opponens pollicis- loss of thumb opposition
  • Deformity: ape thumb deformity (thumb in same pane as palm)

PEN TEST: test for abductor pollicis brevis

MEDIAN NERVE INJURY AT ELBOW

  • Muscles paralysed:
  • Flexor digitorum profundus lateral ½
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis
  • Flexor pollicis longus

Test:

  • pointing index
  • Benediction sign
  • OSCHNER clasp sign

Test for anterior interosseous nerve: motor branch of median nerve supplies flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus lateral 1\2

Tested by OK sign test or KILOH NEVIN sign

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 64

questions.text: A patient was involved in a RTA and sustained fracture of the humerus following which there is loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm, difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Musculocuatneous nerve supplies:

  • Biceps brachi
  • Brachialis
  • Coracobrachialis

These muscle are responsible for flexion and supination at elbow joint

Also musculocuatneous nerve continues as lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm

So, Musculocutaneous nerve injury causes loss of flexion and supination at elbow and sensory loss along the lateral aspect of forearm seen in fracture of humerus

Reference: maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 65
